data.title: Mutiny at Fort Sharpe (1966)
data.meta_description: Because of his difficult character, Colonel Lennox, commanding at Fort Sharp, a remote outpost on the border of the United States is hated by the soldiers of his troop. The situation is even more complicated when the fort is attacked by Indians.
data.text:
Mutiny at Fort Sharpe tells a familiar story about conflicting leadership styles and, for the most part, tells it well. Set in the late days of the American Civil War, the film arranges to trap a group of French soldiers in Texas, in a for which is under the command of Colonel Lenox (Broderick Crawford, in his only spaghetti western). Since Lenox is played by Crawford, we know before we even meet him that he is going to be loud, uncompromising, and difficult; the French troops, meanwhile, are led by a very different man. Fernando Cerchio's spaghetti western Mutiny at Fort Sharpe is often lumped in with the spaghetti westerns made between A Fistful of Dollars and Django, which played out as an awkward mix of American imitation and Italian derivation. But honestly, this film feels like it's imitating not exactly the American western, but the American War epic. There's a clear (if vague) historical backdrop here. Colonial French troops lost in Southern America, trapped between angered Native tribes who will scalp them and trigger-happy "good old boy" rebels who will shoot them. While I can't verify if an incident like the one in the film happened, I can say it allows for a rather novel spaghetti western.
